Itâ€™s pretty simple once you remember perspective (you should learn perspective before this). The eyes and such are above the viewerâ€™s eyeline (horizon line). This will make the lines curve up

The height of the oval does not change. It only changes if youâ€™re thinking in 2d. It is the same height relative to the head in 3d. Remember to always think in 3 dimensions, you may be drawing on a 2d surface but youâ€™re drawing 3d objects

We recommend starting with the Drawing Basics playlist  https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLtG4P3lq8RHHMNwxuVk0IcGRtPGHi4vN9&si=9vZIa0nIyUXPqoc6

There are some diagram sheets you can search for. But there are only going to be so many on one page.  The Loomis method is exactly that: a method. It's not about copying those shapes, you learn how it works and apply it every time, not just memorize all the results.  Try following along with some more of these videos and learn the "why" and "how" of it!
Thank YOU!

Learning where and how to place the features is a good idea to learn before we really spend a lot of time learning detailing and rendering.  But doing a little exploring with making more rendered pieces while still learning to make the Loomis method intuitive for you is okay as a treat.
Always good to revisit the fundamentals!

It's been 10 years since I saw this video. I know I'm just some random comment that will be lost in the huge sea of comments you get in your already big channel. I remembered that time this channel only had around 300k subscribers, but I just wanted to thank you for this video because this was the very video that kickstarted the pursuit of my career in art. 10 years ago I was working in the banking industry and I really hated it. And then one day an artist friend of mine (I also would like to thank him as well, he knows who he is) recommended this video, and for the first time, I actually gained some knowledge on how to draw a head properly. Ever since then I kept practicing, drew almost every day, and joined some workshops. Now I am working as a Gaming Artist reaching my first year in the industry by next week. So from the bottom of my heart, thank you for changing my life for the better and helping me pursue my passion.

Bless your drawing skills and art knowledge! This video has changed my life. I have only ever been able to draw decently from reference and wanted to learn this technique so I wouldn't always be dependent upon references. I've been trying to learn Loomis' method from that very book, or a later edition of it, FOR MONTHS and kept feeling I was missing a step, because everything would look okay from one angle, but they got wonky when I tilted or turned the head. It's been excruciating. Something did not compute and upon seeing this video, I see what was missing. The dimensions of the oval on the side were NEVER given. No wonder I couldn't get things to look quite right. THANK YOU and love to you! <3

I think this video is funny because I ended picking up a bunch of Andrew Loomis art books a few years back and really only cracked the "Fun With a Pencil" book and that didn't produce the results I wanted, do I scratched that idea and looked elsewhere. Then I stumbled across this video and the YouTubers simplification of Loomis' Drawing the Head & Hands book suddenly found its way off my book shelf and into my hands. Then I cracked the book, took a look, and went back to the video. ğŸ™„ But, this video reminded me that Loomis really was the man when it came to drawing. Just need to get past his archaic feeling writing and teaching style to learn what he has for me. Hopefully, the rest of you aren't so foolish as to ignore Loomis' work like I did. ğŸ˜¥

I thought this was really over complicating things. My tutor (credit where credit is due) was a fantastic artist and to prevent us from over thinking and making things more difficult than needs be, he always said it's easy to draw, "if you can draw a line then you can draw anything, it's simply putting the lines in the correct places". That is a credo that has always been with me. As for faces its all a case of proportion. Nose being the length of the ears and as wide as the inside corners of the eyes. The eyes are actually halfway down the whole head. The mouth as wide as the centre of the eyes and so on and so on. It is all in proportion , unless of course your name is John merrick. Good luck though.

Big fan of Proko's videos! Have been studying the Loomis method for some time now, and I feel there are a couple of slips in proko's otherwise awesome explanation (correct me if I am the one in error) : a) The circle in perspective inside the sphere is not merely an oval, it is specifically an ellipse b) At 2:10, Proko mentions that when tilting the head upwards/downwards, the "angle" changes accordingly. While the line does rotate, the orientation of the ellipse's minor axis should remain the same (and not rotate as seen on the video) - the minor axis should point to the left vanishing point and since the camera or the plane of the ellipse doesn't shift change in any way, the vanishing point (and the orientation of the ellipse) should stay unaltered! c) ...and a question: At 3:23 Proko clarifies that the face centerline should be at the center of the frontplane, not the head-width. aren't these two the same? Could someone explain why?

For people still watching this I found a method for drawing a circle that works really well for me and ight work for you too. One mistake I see a lot of people do is drawing a circle with too much wrist action. "Giggidy". Instead concentrate on the back of your elbow. Make a few rotations in the area as if you are tracing an invisible circle but instead use only your shoulder to do the rotation. Ensure your wrist is not bent and your elbow is close to your chest. Your goal is to get a wrist that lines up with your forearm. Concentrating at the back of your elbow is a good way to focus on this movement. Once you've made a few roations in the air you like, drop your arm to the paper and repeat the same motion, using just your shoulder while concentrating on the back of your elbow. Press lightly because the friction of the paper is what causes a lot crazy lines. The lighter you stroke "giggidy" the last friction so therefore the smoother the circle will be.  This movement works so much better for me because of the greater control afforded by the larger engaged muscle groups. It works for me and hopefully this helps you all.

Andrew Loomis lives on. Although he did talked about a special method that he uses professionally called the Blocking method. Though this method you illustrate is great for beginners where you just combine standard primitives together in a Boolean fashion. The Blocking method is far superior as you will have to invent your own primitives. So instead of slicing the edge off a sphere and sticking a rectangle for the jaws, you instead invent a new primitive that closely resemble a skull and flesh it out from there. It's why he emphasize so much on skull, tendons, muscles and fat.

Â Many other people making tutorialsÂ just say the following, when drawing human or cartoonish characters with tilted faces: "Since we see the character from this side, and the face is slightly tilted forward, I place the ears slightly higher, and a larger portion of the side of the head will be visible." That's not good for educational purposes... I always the started thinking things like: "How much higher should the ear be placed, and what will it look like when tilted? How much more visible will the side of the head be? Will the proportions of the face still be correct?" This is the first guide I've come across that in an easy way explains where to place guidelines and what they are for, as well as ensuring that the proportions are right... That led to me drawing three handsome guys. Only 97 to go. Thank you so much. :D

LOL my technique for drawing heads at angles other than 'portrait' or 'profile' is to just draw and hope for the best, while hopefully scrapping it less than 4 times! Next I just draw the "face cross" to give me the layout of the key features. I have to rely on "seeing the head in my head" before I draw it. Usually works okay but it can be really confusing at some angles when you know how it SHOULD look, but you cant seem to translate it to paper. I find heads looking up or down are quite easy though because the circular nature of the top of the head is more apparent and the shallow U curve the eyes will sit on make the downward angle even more obvious. This way seems to make it nice & systematic though so theres no guess work or pure hit-n-miss.

Yeah, I really don't see why being left handed would count as a handicap to drawing? Many artists were and are lefthanded. And most art is really about practicing. Drawing is a skill. Skills can be acquired.Â  To varying degrees certainly.
Leonardo Da Vinci was left handed, thats the reason he wrote in much mirror script, beacause its also easier for left handed people when they write like this.

I'm also left-handed, and I don't think it's a handicap. Being left-handed is only a handicap when writing from left to right (because you have to push the pencil forward instead of gently pulling it towards you, and your hand will smudge what you write).Â  I also read somewhere that the ratios between left-handed and right-handed people are different depending on which group you're looking at. There is a higher ratio of left-handed people that are artists, than left-handed people in the population in general. Interesting, huh? :D

Dude, this is for beginners. This is an aide to help beginners, who can't draw faces, break the face down into basic geometric shapes. Beginners should start with typical, average faces, from many different angles. Once they master that, they can try altering the dimensions of the facial features.

I always start with drawing the nose first and making sure it's the right shape. From then I judge the length of the nose to the length of one of the eyes, then making sure it's in the right place. Same goes for the mouth and making sure it's the right shape. After I'm satisfied the face is right then everything else falls into place. I was always a natural at drawing, but there's a lot of people who will simply never be able to draw something as complex as the face.

From my life drawing experience I've found that usually the jaw line is slightlyï»¿ further back than the vertical on side plane. But it also varies from person to person. Loomis puts it right on that line. I think maybe he tried to simplify it? Saying "slightly further back, sometimes" isn't simple.

One question, though: You put the end of jaw line (near the ear lobe) a little bit back from the vertical line on the side of the head.
